passages.label: START
passages.text:
Summer time is cruel to Bootscrape. The old blacksmith
shop is even hotter than usual – yet just as chaotic as
ever. There's been a great influx of customers since the
first cases of the plague, folks are scared.

They've seen the shambling corpses. The villagers want
to fight fire with fire, may the Light illuminate their path.

passages.label: c01
passages.text:
I sometimes lose sight of why I'm here in the first place.
Customers come and go, they leave their requests.
Apprentice work is no easy task.

The master blacksmith's not much of a talker, she'd rather
keep to herself, and so would I.
I must keep sight. I must not forget my task, my quest.

passages.label: c02
passages.text:
A ring, the doorbell. It manages to reach my ears
through the relentless crackling of our fires.

Were it not for the hot furnace spitting beside me, I could
swear the air got somehow colder as the door loudly
thumped open. It's nice to feel anything other than the
torrid, heavy air of our little shop–
But this breeze carries an unnatural tinge.
I look at the door, a hooded figure walks in.

I take a deep breath, a hard swallow.
This is the moment I've been waiting for.
Shortcake, go fetch us the harp'n order, will ya?

I undo the leather covers of the weapon as I lay it on
the counter. A finely crafted war harpoon, designed for
both intense fishing and for doing battle – an unusual
tool of war, no doubt.

The master blacksmith gets to counting the ancient
gold coins dumped from out customer's ragged purse.
I never thought I'd see dragon coins so long after the war.

Shortcake, don't go both'rin' our customer like that, we
don' refuse no kind o'money here at Isabella's smithy,
a'ight?

Didn't mean much by that, I was only wondering where
our customer's from.

Well, you ain't gettin' no'ere as a blacksmith-in-training
being so in-dis-crete, shortcake. You ne'er know who you'
dealin' wit, an' sometimes it's better to keep it that way.
You must be a foreigner as well, blacksmith's apprentice.

The master blacksmith and I both freeze. Neither of us
were expecting such an exquisite voice to emanate from
under that dark mess of robes. The master blacksmith
exhales, trying to calm herself down.

Of course I assume so from not having seen you here
before, when I came by to place my order.
Isn't that right, Isabella?

Tha's right, this here's Lydia, she arrived a couple 'eeks
ago. Business' warmin' up thes'days, y'see. Even an' ol'
soot-covered beaut' like me can use a young'r hand
smacking' the anvils for'er.
She's from down below, by the coast.
Of course she is.

Quite the worker this one, tell 'ye! Did most o'the work
on this here beaut' o'yours.

Isabella turns to me for a quick wink before turning back
and handing over the harpoon. She lies, of course – the
harpoon was all her work, mostly done by the time I've
arrived.

She likes to hype me up, trying to build up my
reputation. She'd make a fine master; were I here for
learning.

The hooded figure holds up the harpoon with their sharp,
well covered fingers.
A beautiful weapon. What fine craftsmanship.

We prefer the term "craft-s-woman-ship if you don' giv'it
no mind.
Yes, of course.

I can swear the figure under the hood is looking straight
into my eyes as they mutter every word.

It bothers me. I've been waiting for this moment for so
long, and now here I stand, blushing at the foolish
compliments of a vile being. What pains me the most is
how I must stand in silence as I'm scrutinized.

My orders are to hold back and bid my time at moments
like this. I cannot attack.

With things how they are these days, anything that can
fend off the sick and the undead makes for a popular
order. I'm sure your harpoon will make short work of any
shambling corpse that crosses its path.

The hooded figure lays the weapon back down the
counter.
Why, isn't that just marvelous?

I suppose we can do the Holy Light's work before it
intervenes, right, boss?

The master blacksmith's not a believer, she doesn't reply.
Her eyes spell murder, why am I being insolent all of a
sudden? Am I– am I trying to show off?

Lydia, isn't this Light supposed to protect us all? Rather
than just the ones who walk upright, unspoiled by
disease. Disease the Light itself seems to allow to run
rampant across the land.
The Light favours the kind. Those who perish must atone.

The people who are dying, those consumed by the
plague. Are those by any means unkind?

I silence myself before I get in trouble. The master
blacksmith lays her hand on my shoulder, a not so light
squeeze follows.

Now ain't you both justs quite the same piece o'pie,
bickerin' like that. I swear I've never seen Lydia blabber'n'
that much. I guess her next less'n should be 'bout knowin'
when to keep her mouth shut round paying' customers.

Please forgive 'er if she's been offendin'ya, or all o'any
o'your beliefs, m'good personage.

I take no offence. It makes me more than happy to find
someone willing to hold this sort of hearty conversation.
It is not often that I find such a chance.

Fine then, Lydia will be packin' this 'ere weapon again so
our lov'ly cust'mer can leave while they' still 'appy, ain't
that right, Lydia?
Right away, master blacksmith.

As I reach for the harpoon, my hands brush against the
customer's hands, they hastily pull them back. As I grasp
the weapon, it feels much colder than before – as if the
light Isabella spent so long pouring into it had vanished.
A shiver runs up my back bone.

I shall be on my way, then. Thank you for your services,
Isabella, Lydia.
Please come again if y'need anything!

I begin mouthing something meaningless, when the
hooded figure turns back to me, and speaks.
Lydia...

My heart skips a beat. A drop of sweat runs down my
forehead, the furnace now sounds so distant. Why 
pronounce my name like that? Do they know something I
don't? Is there something they're doubting?

I wonder if you share my plight. You seek someone to
talk to, don't you? You should come visit my castle.
The blacksmith laughs a sincere laugh. I feel uneasy.

Oh, my! That's be a bit too inappropriate, I think! 'Sides,
she wouldn't 'ave the time, an–
A second thought. A wild opportunity. I can't refuse this.
Does tomorrow work for you?
Tomorrow would be suitable.
I'll be joining you for breakfast, then.

I am not one for morning gatherings. Would dinner be to
your taste?
It's settled, dinner at your castle it is.

Soon enough the door closes as they leave. My heart races
as the hot, steamy climate of the shop builds itself back
up. I'm already sweating. I din't think this opportunity
would present iself so soon – definitely not how it did.
The next day.

The sun is beginning to set down outside of the
blacksmith shop. I've taken care not to overwork myself
despite the master blacksmith's efforts to push onto me
whatever she could think of.

Isabella isn't being her usual self. She keeps giving me
that disappointed look I've never seen before.

As time nears for me to take leave, she finally decides to
speak up. I already have my cape thrown over my
shoulder.
So... Ye' really goin', then?
I nod.
Well! What if I say I won't allow it?!

By now you should now there is nothing you can do
about this.
She sighs.

Lydia, shortcake, you may be thinkin' I don't know
nothin' 'bout what you're up to.

Does she know of– she couldn't! Could she?! Every
precautionary measure has been taken!
Oh.

That’s what this is all about. She worries that the
Necromancer will break my heart. She has no clue – I am
the one about to crush theirs.
I see no reason for you to–
Shortcake, you should see care with what you’ be messin’ with.
She's serious.

Talk ‘round town is the Necromancer’s been gath’rin’ all
sorts of undead thralls from their there town
o’Boulderchip. City’s completely run over by t’plague,
shortcake.
You’ve seen my work. You know I can hold my own.
I sound so confident I could convince myself.

You’re more than one hell of an unb’lievably amazin’ 
‘prentice, Lydia. Almost too good to be true. Although
not a full’n realized blacksmith, y’do hold the potential
to become one.
I nod a guilty nod and tighten the hold on my keys.
But you’re clearly somethin’ else.
I stare into her tired eyes. I guess she did see through me after all.
You can take Suzana along. Maybe she can keep up with‘ya.

Suzana’s not ideal. If I had a choice, I’d go with any other
stronger mare from the local stable, I can surely afford
one.
I feel like I don’t really have a choice.

Thank you, master blacksmith. Isabella. I don’t know if
I’ll be back. I’d like to thank you for everything you’ve
taught me.

Oh, you darn– you can’t fool me nothin’! Get y’ass goin’
outta here ‘fore I change m’mind.

passages.label: c03
passages.text:
She sounds disappointed. I shut the door behind me and
head for the worn watering post behind the shop.

That’s why I despise this whole "undercover agent" bit.
Had I not to conceal myself, I could just strike down the
Necromancer without deceiving any good souls such as
old Isabella.
I undo the bindings and set the saddle on Suzana, Isabella’s mare.
With a short chant I summon back Brightmaiden, my divine warhammer, back to my hands. It’s been hidden beneath the soil, as eager as I am for this moment.

passages.label: c04
passages.text: Boulderchip is not far from Bootscrape, but the road itself can be tricky. People have settled by the roadside in makeshift tents and huts, they carry the plague.
Some of them dare venture near travellers, they beg for coin and bread. The sicker ones, by broken minds, beg to be put out of their misery.
I can see some bodies lying here and there, those should be burned, I lack the the time for mudly rites.
It’s not like I haven’t been through this road many times before. I’ve had my share of late night walks under the master blacksmith’s nose.
I’ve been keeping my eyes on the Necromancer, as much as I could. Yet I’ve surely never been so close as I’ll soon be.
Despite the awful stench of decomposing matter, I can already smell Boulderchip’s river. I won’t be long now.
Suzana’s trotting becomes more of a drag as the sun begins disappearing under the horizon. I light my lamp and prod her along.
We keep slumbering through the road as the winds keeps blowing through the pallid, dried up trees around us. Each dead leaf sings a song of its own.
A feral roar thunders through the air, the branches on the trees almost seem to shake.
Suzana rears, I slide and fall with my back against the ground. The lamp smashes and burns out, everything goes dark.
How did I not think this through? What a fool I am, not even considering for a second that I could be ambushed by the Necromancer at any time!
I get up and muster my faith to summon a spot of the Holy Light – a true believer has no need for lamps.
Another roar. Something dashes near my side, so fast that I must brace myself to keep from falling down again.
Suzana doesn’t share in my steadfastness, the mare runs away into the night with all of the speed and determination she didn’t bother using just a while ago.
I reach for my hammer, then I finally manage to work out the dark scene taking place before my eyes.
What seems to be an old lady is being cornered by what seems to be a Zombie-Skeleton-Man-Boar.
Besides thanking the Light it’s not the Necromancer, my first thought is to help the poor lady at once. But I’m still undercover. That’s what I’m told. Until the Necromancer is taken care of.
There’s no way I would leave an old lady to die by the hands of this undead creature. Besides, I must give its soul a peaceful rest.

Yes. Were I to follow my orders, I'm to hide and take mental note of all that happens, so I can better prepare against the true enemy. Yet–
I can no longer deny justice to those who deserve it.
I cannot allow an innocent old lady to perish by the hands of the undead.
I brandish my hammer, and muster the Holy Light to illuminate my path, for the souls of the damned must be put to rest, so the living may persevere!
ROLL FOR INITIATIVE
Oh, thank you so much for helping an old nobody like me! Who is it that I owe my life to?
Would she trust me more were I to lie? I’m done telling lies.

I am Lydia, Paladin of the Order of the Chamber of Light.
Are you injured, miss..?
Oh I’m– I’m fine, thank you. It’s not the first time I run into something nasty along this road.
Would you allow me to guide you to your destination? It is dangerous to wander about these roads at this time.
Oh, I’ll be alright, I know my way around.
If you must, may I bother you with the curiosity of an old lady? What does a Paladin like yourself in commoner’s clothing, crossing the dirty roads between two sad little country villages?
I should at the very least be careful when speaking of my duties. The old lady doesn’t seem concerned at all, knowing who I am.
I’m on a quest. I’m heading to Boulderchip’s castle.
Oh, so the Chamber is finally taking action against the Necromancer, I see...
You know of the Necromancer? I mean– Are you sure you don’t want me to escort you somewhere safe?
Oh, don’t you give it a second thought! You have much more important matters to attend to. Your path is one I wouldn’t dare cross.
What if you’re attacked again?!
What’s one more treacherous crossing compared to the future I’m sure you’ll bring? Once you fulfill your destiny, young Paladin... And old lady like me will have nothing more to fear.
May that be the path of the Light, milady.
I’ll be on my way, then. Good luck!
May the bright keep on living.
She disappears beyond the shadows.
What an odd encounter.
With Suzana nowhere to be seen, I won’t possibly arrive on time.

passages.label: c05
passages.text: I arrive at the castle stinking like a beaten hog. The moon’s high in the sky, my cape drags over the dirt, I undid it a while ago to make way for my own sweat. I’m not proud of how much I had to run to make it in time.
The last thing that should be bothering me is the state of my dress and hair, but as soon as I make it to the main gate, I get a whisper of embarrassment as the intimidating guards stare me down.
It is unlike a Paladin to feel self conscious about her appearance!

I take a good look at the guards, they are certainly very much undead. The one on the right has a flaming skull for a head, which just doesn’t seem very convenient at all, though I suppose it does makes for good imagery.
They are both very tall and corpulent.
WHAT BRINGS YOU TO THIS ESTATE, MY LADY? ARE YOU RECENTLY DECEASED?
Not yet.
Well, are you dying then? She doesn’t look like she’s dying!
Your barony has invited me for dinner.
The guards laugh and bang their heavy spears to the ground. I can tell those spears were forged by Isabella – if we fight, they won’t be easy to break.
Why do you laugh?
THE MIGHTY NECROMANCER OF BOULDERCHIP WOULD NEVER COURT SOMEONE SO... LIVELY!
They both laugh and bang their spears some more.
Would you venture a guess that perhaps they intend to take my life away, then?
Why would you you think that of our master?
NO LIVES ARE TAKEN HERE MILADY. THE NECROMANCER OFFERS US NOTHING MORE THAN A SECOND CHANCE AT WHAT WE’VE LOST.
Despite the flaming skull head, and that voice that sounds like the screams of the damned, the guard does have a way with words.
Wouldn’t you like to know what’s beyond the Mud? What comes after?
Most of us didn’t ever get the chance to see what’s on this side. We are born among the plague, and then we die. That’s no life. I’d rather get to know this world before any other.
What a weird way to think. I wonder if they have any idea of how much they stand in defiance to the way of the Light. May it forgive their crimes against the natural order.
YOU REALLY DON’T KNOW ANYTHING ABOUT THE MIGHTY NECROMANCER, DO YOU?
I must do my best to keep appearances for now, I’m so close.
The Chamber has told me all that I need to know, that the Necromancer is raising an army of the dead, that they will soon cover the land, and march all over the Mud, in a reign of chaos.
I’ve heard all of the rumours. That they are a practitioner of black magic, that they bring the dead to undeath, and make those serve them.
What is your family trade, my lady?
I apprentice under the master blacksmith of Bootscrape.
And I suppose you have a name?
I do.
WITFUL TAUNT, MORTAL.
Well, blacksmith’s apprentice from Bootscrape, I am but a guard at the gates of the Boulderchip Castle. Me and my husband, we used to be merchants before the plague reached our village.
JUST YOU IMAGINE BEING AROUND SO MANY TYPES OF PEOPLE EVERYDAY. THERE WAS NO WAY WE WOULDN’T END UP GETTING IT. THE PLAGUE.
After he died I couldn’t keep on living all by myself. Yet I dreaded the thought of letting the plague consume my flesh and break my mind.
SO THE NECROMANCER GRANTED US A FAVOR WE NOW PAY FOR WITH OUR SERVITUDE.

I do my best not to lash out in righteous fury. Such blasphemy. How can those two not see that they are being manipulated and enslaved by a Necromancer who had no right denying their path of Light in the first place?
Does the spell of undeath also bind their wills?
Has your master no mercy, giving you unlife only to serve under their domain?
Well, blacksmith’s apprentice from Bootscrape, if you’re unconvinced... why don’t you come in and see for yourself?
THAT’S RIGHT! HAVE YOU NOT BEEN INVITED?!
The guards laugh once more, genuinely entertained by standing against me.
If you don’t believe me, so be it. Rest assured, though, it is unwise to stand in my way.
I stand tall, puff my chest, broaden my shoulders, doing my best to seem intimidating. They laugh and bang their spears even louder.
Oh, blacksmith’s apprentice from Bootscrape, no more, we yield, please, we’re already dead! Don’t make us die once more from laughter!
I will ask the zombutler if your visit is expected. You wait here.
The guard limps slowly to stage right and into the castle. I can’t wait much longer, I can feel a slight tremble at the tips of my fingers.
EVEN IF YOU DO MAKE YOUR WAY IN, AND FACE OUR MASTER– EVEN IF YOU ARE THE THREAT YOU THINK YOU ARE. I CAN SEE THROUGH YOU, ENTERPRISING VANQUISHER.
YOU ARE NOT STRONG ENOUGH TO DEFEAT THE NECROMANCER.
How do you– why would you say that?!
THE LADY OF THE HOUSE HAS GIVEN ME WORD OF YOUR COMING, SHE SEES DAYS YET TO COME. THE NECROMANCER IS STRONGLY WARDED BY BOTH HER MAGIC AND THE CASTLE ITSELF.
THEY CANNOT BE DEFEATED WHILE THE WALLS STAND, AND WHILE US SERVANTS STILL TRUST THEM.
That’s a lot to take in. I stare puzzled at the flaming skull monster as I try to understand what’s that all about.
I hear distant laughter nearing. The other guard is back, barely able to keep from falling to pieces as it huffs and puffs in between cackles.
So! Blacksmith’s apprentice from Bootscrape! You’ve really been invited! From what I heard, our master has taken quite a liking for you– Who would’ve thought?! A living girl!
My face feels like burning up, I shouldn’t let this get to me.
I suppose you shouldn’t worry about me harming my admirer, then.
YOU SHALL FIND THE NECROMANCER TO BE QUITE THE CHARMER.
I feel an urge to smite those blasphemous fools where they stand, but I must keep my cover, for just a while longer.

passages.label: c14
passages.text: As I’m escorted through the gates all I can think about is how much I just want to summon the Holy Light and raze this whole place to the ground.
I suppose the Chamber wouldn’t forgive me if they found out I’ve ruined their quest because I couldn’t handle being made fun of.
We follow a decrepit brick pathway leading to the main hall. Now that I’m inside, I’m a bit surprised.

passages.label: c06
passages.text: One would assume an undead retreat to smell of decaying corpses and other horrendous things. The halls inside the Necromancer’s castle seem very well cleaned, the smell is of freshly cut herbs.
Ah, yes, I forgot to mention– Our master isn’t home yet. You’ll have to wait until they arrive from their campaign.
I ADVISE AGAINST GOING AROUND CAUSING TROUBLE. UNLESS YOU WANT TO BECOME SOMEONE’S DINNER BEFORE YOU HAVE YOURS!
So do make yourself comfortable. And feel free to explore the castle!
Their laughter echoes around the hall as they stumble away, leaving me all alone. I wouldn’t describe myself as feeling comfortable.

I suppose I do have some time to kill. I should take this chance to gather whatever I can about this place and about the Necromancer. The guard did mention something about the castle walls being warded.
Where should I go first?

passages.label: dinnerhall
passages.text: The dinner hall, this is where I’ll be meeting with the Necromancer. I better get to know the place, it might as well end up becoming a battleground.

passages.label: c06
passages.text: I make my way to the door. As I reach for the handle, an odd, white, spectral mass protrudes from the center of the door itself.
It’s a ghost, a very small ghost. They frown at me – as if I’ve just insulted them – and speaks in a high pitched tone.
It’s not very polite to eat before you go on a date!
It’s not a date–
Not to you, anyway!
The ghost fades back into the door. I try the handle, it’s locked.
I guess I’ll try again later, where else may I go?

passages.label: kitchen
passages.text: I enter the kitchen expecting dismembered corpses and unholy tinctures.

passages.label: c07
passages.text: The first thing to hit me, though, is the heavenly smell of baked potatoes and roasted beef. There are two skeletons stirring the biggest cauldron I’ve ever seen.
Hurry up! Hurry on! Before the Necromancer’s home!
You can say that to the stew! I can’t help it a few!
They haven’t noticed me yet. I sneak up behind them, I can’t see inside the cauldron even if I stand on the tips of my toes.
What are you two making?
They get spooked, one of them jumps so hard that their skull pops off and into the cauldron, their friend helps them fish it out with a big spoon and fix it back in place.
I can’t believe what I’m seeing! Look, it’s someone living!
May I try some of that?
We’ll think about it if you bring us salt!
Where is it?
There, in that drawer, by the buckit!
Didn’t you mean bucket?
Aren’t you glad I didn’t say mullet?
Is that a joke, because I’m bald?!
I just wish this lady would bring us the salt!
As the skeletons continue spewing poor attempts at comedic rhyming, I slide open the drawer. Inside are some bones, a plate of salt, and some dried herbs.
How odd...
The bones don’t look like anything I’ve ever seen, they’re shaped like fish bones, but are way too thick–
Did the plague make you blind? I’ll have the salt if you don’t mind!
Why won’t one of you come here and get it?
Silly question, living fool! We can’t stop stirring until it’s time to cool. If we stop cooking for even a bit, there won’t be nothing for us eat!
I chuckle to myself, entertaining the thought of a pair of skeletons trying to eat a stew. I hand them the salt.
That’s– quite a bit of salt for my dinner.

HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA!
The living truly are fools!
Aren’t those servants? Are they not supposed to be cooking dinner? Maybe I did arrive too early after all.
You can try the stew, living one. But don’t you try to cheat my bone! We’ve been hungry for months, gal. So you can’t have it all.
Were the Necromancer themself to ask for it in a plight... We’d reply: No way! Not tonight!
That’s right. We’ve been cooking this stew since long before the Necromancer arrived at the Castle. They should wait and be respectful, we don’t want to start a battle.
Woah, they’ve been stirring that stew for over an year. I’m not sure those two are servient to their master at all. And I’m definitely not trying this brew.
If they’re not cooking my dinner... Will there ever be a dinner? I fear this might indeed end up being an ambush. The Necromancer couldn’t possibly have figured me out, could they?

passages.label: c06
passages.text: I close the kitchen door behind me as I walk out, tightly grabbing my cape, deep in thought. Where should I go next?

passages.label: library
passages.text: As I explore the castle, I make my way through a dark corridor. I can hear loud voices in the distance. Should I dare venture forth?

passages.label: c08
passages.text: Following the voice, I’m taken to a library so immense I could swear all the books piled down would make their way to Bootscrape and back.
The room is dimly lit by some lamps being carried by oh so many zombies. They don’t seem the evil, flesh eating kind, though.
Some of them are cataloging books, some others are peacefully sitting at the tables, reading in silence.
The loud voices continues, disturbing the peaceful silence.
I just wish there were more opportunities for people like us to teach!
You’re dead! You’re not even people! Ain’t nobody got time to listen to no old fools, what makes you think they’d want to listen to old, dead fools?!
Don’t be like that, Putric... Maybe someone will listen. Maybe... if they learn more about the plague, the living may figure out a cure or something...
Baah! Ain’t nobody got time to listen to you either, Wilson! They all die, sooner or later! I didn’t die of the plague!
I bet you died because of how ugly and creepy you were! So ugly and creepy, in fact, that you know there’s no way anyone would ever listen to anything you tried to teach. You’re bitter, Putric!
Now, now, Wilson. There’s no need for–
The zombies notice my presence, one turns to me. It seems friendly, despite also seeming horrendous.
You right there, young human lady, I can’t possibly imagine what you’re doing at a place like this, but do tell me– Don’t you think my buddy Zombert here would make a dependable professor?
I’m sure he would!
I’m sure I don’t want to make a scene in a room full of zombies.
Why, thank you, young lady. You are very kind to this old decaying corpse.
She’s giving you false expectations, Zombert, can’t you see? Living one, would you let a zombie like me come any near your little brother or sister?
Putric, the cynical zombie, tries to reinforce his point by making a scary face, but his face muscles are too putrid, so it looks more like a sad smile.
No! Of course you wouldn’t! The second we walk out of this estate people will want to bash our heads in, shoot arrows and darts at us! They’ll maim our poor, old corpses, like we’re nothing at all.
The living don’t mingle with the undead, that’s how things are.
Yet here I am, mingling with the undead. What judgement would the Holy Light pass onto me, were I not on duty?
Is it bad to be undead, then?
It’s– It’s better than just being dead.
But shouldn’t we all die one day? To follow the natural course of life and death, to find peaceful rest?
I do my best not to mention the path of Light.
We will sure all die one day, young lady. But for now, we make the best of our unlives by learning as much as we can. Who knows how the Mud will be a few years from now?
If you bothered to listen to our grievances, maybe I will have a chance to teach before I’m rotten out of existence.
Wilson nods enthusiastically.
I could sure use some peaceful rest far away from you rosy-cheek jokers...
Putric slumps over the table and buries his head under his arms.

passages.label: c06
passages.text: A zombie who wants to be a professor, the very thought of it is entirely out of this world. As I mull it over in my mind, I wander out of the library. By the time I realize, I’ve already made my way back to the hall.
Where should I go next?

passages.label: upperhall
passages.text: As I near an ornate set of stairs, I hear what sounds like music coming from above. It gets louder as I climb up to the upper hall. I look beyond the archway, I gasp in shock and awe.
Dozens of couples are dancing all around the upper hall, they’re all ghosts. Their spectral shapes float up and down the floor as they dance like no living being ever could.
Even the band is phantasmagoric, translucent undead fingers plucking astral strings and banging on spirit drums.
What more can black magic achieve? I only want to feel horrified, but I am, in truth, mesmerized just as much.
A ghost breaks away from their partner and floats over to me.
Miss, would I be right to assume that you’re somehow– alive?
Yes I am, my lady.
Oh, by the Light! I’ve been waiting for so long! Waiting for a living being to walk through these doors... well, anyone with a physical body, really.
I need a drink, miss, you have no idea how much I need this. Would you prepare me one? Would you do this favor for a poor old ghost?
Did she mention the Light? Was this ghost once a believer? I look around and see the ghosts passing through each other. The poor things can’t really touch anything.
It’s not their fault they’ve been condemned to eternal partying.
I– I guess I can, ma’am.
I make my way to an old table at the corner of the room, one covered in bottles of what must have once been fine liquor. Old spirits, if you will.
I pour a mixture of... something, something wet, yet barely liquid. I hand it over to the ghost.

She manages to hold the glass through the veil long enough to throw the liquid down her lips, through her throat and the rest of her body, the drink spills all over the wood flooring, and the glass soon follows.
She doesn’t seem to mind.
Thank you kindly. I’m Margot, by the way.
I’m Lydia, a follower of the Light. Are you a believer, Margot?
She ignores my question, I suppose it didn’t make it through the veil.
It’s been so long since a living person came to this castle. Someone not stained by the plague, that is. Oh my, are you dying of the plague, Lydia?
No, I’m fine.
Oh, I should’ve known. You look so young and healthy, so full of life. May the Light illuminate your path!
I suppose the last living person who came by was Mavut, and that wasn’t so long ago... Though you can’t really consider a Necromancer to be exactly living all that much.
Their name is Mavut.
It’s good to see someone like you. Ooh, I envy your plump skin, and your fluffy hair. Enjoy those while they last.
You– you miss those.
Do I miss being alive? Yes, of course I do.
Something tells me it’d rude to ask her why not just die already if undeath isn’t cutting it.
The thing is I’m too scared to do anything about my predicament.
Why is that? Does the Necromancer keep you prisoner?

Oh, no! Mavut? The Light bless their soul, they take good care of all of us here, oh, so caring. I’ve been haunting these halls since long before they arrived, even longer than any of the other– any of the other ghosts.
If the Necromancer’s as nice as you say they are, then why won’t they help you with whatever’s troubling you?

Oh, but Mavut... master Mayes has offered me their aid! Many times I’ve come to them with cries for help, and they offer me what I fear... To reverse my undeath, to let me follow my path to the Light...
To know what comes next.
Maybe the Light holds a place for you by its side.
I would like that very much. Do you believe it’d be so? Were I to... go?
Yes, I do.

Well, I– I guess I’ll give it some thought...
For some more decades. I just hope Mavut will still be around when I make up my mind.
I can only hope you’ll make the right decision, Margot.
Thank you so much, living girl. For the great drink, and the great talk. My partner must be waiting for me, I hope to see you again someday. Or... Maybe not! Ha ha ha!
She floats back up and disappears into the mob of dancing specters. What a nice lady. I hope she finds the Light.

passages.label: c06
passages.text: I climb back down the way I came, a bit dizzy from watching the ghosts, and from the vapours of whatever it was I’ve managed to concoct from those old spirits. Where should I go next?

passages.label: dungeon
passages.text: Through a maze of stairs and corridors, I somehow make my way down into the castle’s dungeons. I’m afraid there will be nothing pleasant to find here.
While the undead seemed happy enough at the upper floors, waltzing around and having small talk, I’m sure the dungeons would be where the Necromancer keeps their meanest prisoners and vilest thralls.

passages.label: c09
passages.text: I firmly grasp my hammer and keep moving.
To my surprise, the cells are mostly empty. The ones I do find occupied are visibly unlocked.
Some have zombies and other undead monsters sleeping in them. When I do find some unfriendly-looking skeletons, I’m almost disappointed to find out they’re just upset over a heated game of dice.
I’ve been wandering for a while now, when I come upon an odd... tent? It’s built right in the middle of a corridor, blocking the path. A fog-like smoke seems to envelop me, where is it coming from?
I step near the tent, wary. An oddly familiar voice greets me from the inside.
Well, good evening milady! Will you be coming in? I can tell you about your future!
A fortune teller? The Chamber would never allow this, it’s dark magic. But why does that voice sound so familiar? Should I go through with sacrilege and walk into that tent?

passages.label: yesfortune
passages.text: May the Light forgive my curiosity. I’ve never been to a fortune teller before. I suppose my quest does require me to fit in to my surroundings, what could possibly go wrong?

passages.label: c10
passages.text: I walk into the tent. A woman in exotic dresses sits over a pillow in front of a short table. She wears a veil over her face, and gestures for me to sit with her. I give a prayer to the Light and do her bidding.
Don’t be shy, don’t be scared. I don’t bite, I’m not even undead, I swear! Here, I’ll just lay some of these cards on the table, and all you have to do is pick whichever one you like...

She lays the cards. She must be a Cartomancer. This is a much higher form of sacrilege than any regular fortune telling. The magics those cards hold are much stronger than anything a mere witch could ever handle.
I suppose it’s too late for me to turn back now.
Go on, love. Just pick a card, any card.

passages.label: lawfulfortune
passages.text: She shows me the Two of Swords.
Yes, the Two of Swords. I see there’s doubt clouding your sight. You’re unsure if what you’re doing is right, if evil truly is what it seems.
You’re not eager to make the decision you believe you must, you don’t want to wind up regretting a missed opportunity.
From underneath the card she’s just shown me – was there a card underneath that one?! – she raises the Three of Swords.
Oh, love, I see betrayal. This is the Three of Swords, see? There will be a price to pay for what you want. Are you willing to lose something in order to get what you came for?

passages.label: neutralfortune
passages.text: She shows me the Two of Swords.
Yes, the Two of Swords. I see there’s doubt clouding your sight. You’re unsure if what you’re doing is right. If evil truly is what it seems.
You’re not eager to make the decision you must, you don’t want to lose the trust of those you’ve come to love.
From underneath the card she’s just shown me – was there a card underneath that one?! – she raises the Five of Swords.
There’s no doubt you can follow the path laid down for you. What will it cost you? You’ll have to consider who will be hurt in the process.
To change is not a sign of weakness, to be able to recognize your faults and to make things right might prove to be your greatest strength.

passages.label: chaoticfortune
passages.text: She shows me the Two of Swords.
Yes, the Two of Swords. I see there’s doubt clouding your sight. You’re unsure if what you’re doing is right. If evil truly is what it seems.
You’re not eager to make the decision you must, I suppose you must be afraid you won’t know what to do with overwhelming power.
From underneath the card she’s just shown me – was there a card underneath that one?! – she raises the Moon.
Sometimes you must trust yourself before you do anyone else. The decision ahead of you is a grave one, doing the right thing by your logic alone might take more courage that you have.
True answers often lie deep within our feelings. You’ll never find those answers by mulling things over in your head.

passages.label: endfortune
passages.text: I’m overtaken by unnatural dread. Is she right? I certainly have no right to believe her, and yet – it feels right.
Paladins of the Chamber are to burn and debase all prophecies not delivered by the Light, but– I can’t deny that those cards have revealed something I’ve been refusing to see.

passages.label: c09
passages.text: We say our farewells and I step out of the tent. I suppose I’m done here.

passages.label: nofortune
passages.text: By the Light, never! The Chamber forbids those dark rites. The Light refuses to illuminate such a fiendish path! Fortune telling is dark magic, and I shalln’t abide.

A small woman steps out of the tent, she wears exotic dresses and a veil over her face. Her gait is tired, her frame is frail, yet she carries the aura of someone who’s in total control of their surroundings.
She speaks in that same familiar voice.
Do you fear the cards, my lady? Dare I say– do you fear they might lie to you?
I– I fear not your unholy scryings, fortune teller. S– stand back! I shall fear no darkness as long as the Holy Light illuminates my path!
I turn back and make my leave, a feeling of unease makes me wonder how courageous did I truly sound like, how courageous I truly am.

passages.label: leavedungeon
passages.text: As I reach the stairs leading out of the dungeons, I hear the fortune teller once again.
This path that your "Light" illuminates ahead of you; what shall become of you once it comes to an end?
How dares that fortune teller follow me? To mock my faith, no less?! I turn to face her, to warn her of my might.
Nothing.
All I find is an empty dungeon corridor, I hear snoring in the distance, probably from a sleeping zombie. Did I imagine that? Did the fortune teller cast some sort of spell on my perceptions?

passages.label: c14
passages.text: I’ve no time for trickery. I turn back to climb up the stairs...
OLD LADY!
I gasp and cover my mouth, shocked by my own surprised shouting. As I reach the upper floor, the old lady that I've met on the road, Amelia, stands before me. Dressed as the fortune teller, no less.
Did I then risk my life for one of the Necromancer’s servants?
Am I being ambushed? If Amelia, the old lady, is a fortune teller at the Necromancer’s castle, do they know my true identity as well?
If I lose the element of surprise, this goes from the perfect opportunity to defeat the Necromancer to– to an inescapable death-trap.

passages.label: c06
passages.text: As fight or flight kicks in, I’m reminded of the tremendous population of undead monsters inhabiting this castle. I dodge the fortune teller and make a sprint for the front door. Better equip my hamm–
THUD!
I– I ran into someone’s chest.
I take a step back.
Lydia? I’m terribly sorry. Are you hurt?

The Necromancer’s words cut like knives into whatever’s left of my wit. It seems they were just walking in as I was running for the door.
I fail to sputter a response.
My schedule’s been somewhat hectic these days. Did I leave you waiting for too long?
What– how do I answer? Were the Necromancer and the fortune teller in cahoots after all? Why does this vile creature of night sound so... heartfelt?
You did take too long. I was about to leave.
I’m truly, truly sorry. I was attending to... so many pressing matters down at Boulderchip.
Don’t you worry, Mavut. I was keeping company to your guest.
I see you’ve already met Amelia, Lydia.
Oh yes, we’ve met alright. She’s full of worries in her head, that one.
I’m glad I didn’t leave you waiting all by yourself, then. Amelia is a frequent visitor of this estate, I believe she’s been bringing her tent here since long before my own arrival.
Her wisdom is invaluable, it easily overshadows my own.

I’m embarrassingly paralyzed, trying to assess the situation. Even though the fortune teller knew my true identity... Did she withhold that information from the Necromancer? Is she not truly their servant?
Or perhaps she is, I can’t be sure, maybe she just didn’t yet have the time to rat me out. Would she do it? How can I trust this woman, one so prone to trickery?
You flatter me, Mavut.
For a fraction of a second, she turns from smiling at the Necromancer to winking at me – with foxy, old, wrinkly eyes. I’m very much done with these bull droppings.
The Necromancer bows their slender figure in reverence to Amelia.
Now, Amelia, if you’ll excuse us – Lydia and I have plans for tonight.
What should I make of all this? Were those two acting out some sort of rehearsed lie? Will I now be overrun by the undead, only to be brutally executed and brought back to life as a monster?
What sickening revenge would my own deceit bring upon me?
If you’ll follow me, Lydia... I’ll lead the way.

passages.label: c14
passages.text: I measure a thousand questions in my head as they lead me deep inside the castle.
What are you– where are we going?
The Necromancer’s eyes seem to glimmer under their hood.
Well... I did leave you waiting for quite a while. But if you won’t mind waiting just a while longer, I hoped we could engage in one of my favorite activities before dinner.
I can feel the sweat pooling beneath my cape.
Your– wha– what would that activity be?
Killing young, deceitful Paladins.
Ripping off their body parts and feeding those to the undead.
Turning followers of the Light into thralls of darkness.
My, you seem so zealous. Do you not fancy a bout of fishing? I was hoping to catch us a big one for dinner.
I try not to gasp.
Gasp!
I’ve gasped.

Fishing sounds... sane. Noble, even.
I take a deep breath, I must sound collected.
Why, yes. I do quite enjoy fishing.
May the Light forgive my eagerness. I am becoming convinced that the Necromancer is not so bloodthirsty as I’ve been led to believe. I might soon find the perfect chance to strike.

passages.label: c13
passages.text: After navigating the twisted tunnels of the castle for quite a while, we finally walk outside. We’ve arrived at a small deck, it seems to stand over a secluded bend of the Boulderchip river.
Had I known of this secret entrance, I could’ve planned the perfect stealth operation...
The best spot for fishing is over at the deep end. We’ll take the boat. You may leave your cape and belongings here, if you please.
I feel warmth spreading across my nose and cheeks.
Will you be undoing your hood and robe, then?
That would not be appropriate at all.
Of course it wouldn’t.
Then I’m fine as I am, thank you very much.
I only make the suggestion so it’ll be easier for the both of us to row. I meant no offence, you may do as you please, of course.
The Necromancer steps ahead and climbs inside the small rowboat. As they wait for me, I give in and undo my cape, leaving it by the doorstep.
I won’t need it for fighting, anyway – it doesn’t even give me any bonuses to my armor class.

I’m handed a paddle, and asked to row. I take a good look at the Necromancer’s fingers, slender, bony, long. They handle with care and precision, and remind me of the legs of a spider weaving its web.
Those same unholy fingers now point ahead, into the darkest spot of the slow-running waters.

passages.label: c11
passages.text: We begin rowing together in silence.
If the Necromancer’s plotting anything, they’re not letting it on any more then I am. Dark robed arms row calmly and effortlessly as I try and manage to keep up. I hear– I hear humming.
Is the Necromancer humming a funeral march?
What the– I see lights under the water. Could it be? I can’t believe what I’m seeing, it’s the fish! Undead fish, with eyes glowing like bright lamps under the water!

passages.label: c12
passages.text: How far will dark magic go?!
You look surprised, Lydia. Never seen zombie fish?
People don’t get to see a lot of the undead where I’m from.

I remember the words of the Highest Priestess of the Order of the Chamber of Light. Dark magic wouldn’t flourish if it weren’t seducing by its very nature. But by the might of the Light, it is punishable by death!
Have you ever done fishing by your own hands? I mean, without fishing poles and barbed hooks, that is.
Not once.
The Necromancer appears to... wiggle? Could they actually be excited to be inducting me to some sort of weird fishing technique?
Is that common practice where you’re from?
Yes, it is indeed. That’s the right proper way of fishing, it’s how I’ve known to do it for as long as I can remember.
I look around the small boat – it’s empty aside for the both of us.
No rods? Not even nets?
None of these things would have a chance against the fish around here! They are strong, they fight back.
I shiver as the waters become agitated. Something big swims underneath us.
I’m so glad there are such fierce fish on these waters. I used to face many great catches back at my homeland.
They sound longing.
Your homeland. Where was that?
Very far, Lydia.
As we arrive at the darkest, deepest end of the water, our boat comes to a full stop.
By the furthest margin I can see some of the oddest, most twisted trees I’ve ever seen.
They seem to follow the steps of a grim dance in the light wind of the night, with dark, dry-looking fruit hanging from their branches and swinging like ornaments of the macabre.
The Necromancer stands up, the boat wobbles. They raise their hand and growl some sort of incantation.

It must’ve been a fetching cantrip, as some of the dark, rotten fruit from the twisted trees zip through the air and land on our boat. I can’t forget who I’m dealing with – a powerful caster of dark magic.
Before we can catch the fish, we must bring the fiercest, hungriest ones to the surface. They adore the taste of these fruits.
The Necromancer picks up one of the fetched fruits. They tear it into smaller, rotten pieces, and spread those pieces all over the water around us.
And now what?
Now we wait, and do our best to catch one off-guard.
I do the same as they did. I pick up one of the awful, rotten fruits, and spread pieces off it around our boat.
Perhaps the Necromancer is doing the same to me. Baiting and feeding me hope, as they plan the perfect moment to strike me down.
Now we must stand very still, and be very quiet. Ironically, the strongest ones are those more easily scared off.
I can relate.
After a good while, I can finally notice something emerging from the depths.
A light much brighter than any other that’s been swimming around and pecking at the fruit. As it nears, I can see it’s truly a big one, a fish bigger than any horse I’ve ever seen!
Concerned with proving myself an efficient fisherwoman, I reach out under the water and grab it by its dorsal fin. It pulls back, it struggles, it drags us and the boat.
I hold tight, and manage to grab the beast with both hands.
Maybe I didn’t think this whole thing through.
Wha– what next?
Now, Lydia, we fight!
What the– now?! Am I going to be attacked?!
To my surprise, the Necromancer jumps to my side and helps me yank the fish out of the water – we both hurl it towards the shallow end as out boat shakes and wobbles in the dark waters.
With another whispered incantation, the Necromancer sends our boat gliding across the river and towards the now infuriated zombie fish.
I don’t think twice before equipping my hammer as the Necromancer produces the harpoon they’d ordered at Isabella’s. Now, we fight.
ROLL FOR INITIATIVE

passages.label: c11
passages.text: The monstrous fish vanquished, our boat having wandered all the way to the opposite shore, I slip out of the boat and unceremoniously sit down on the ground underneath the twisted, dark trees.
The biggest fish I’ve ever seen in my life is twitching on the ground nearby, defeated.
The Necromancer sits right beside me. I do my best to say something, while still trying to catch my breath.
I can’t believe– well... That was– that was some actual fun.
By the Light, I swear I can spot a smile underneath their hood.

The Necromancer reaches for a dark, rotten, dried up fruit – just like those from before – that had fallen from the tree above us. They hold it in their hand... Oh, Light above, are they going to eat it? How dreadful.
Once again, a reminder that–
The Necromancer whispers an incantation.
I can actually understand some of the words – in between dark, profane biddings, I can actually discern words of Light. After saying those words, they gently blow some air at the rotten fruit.

Wrinkles and bruises flatten out as the fruit slowly swells up; a bright yellow color spreads over it, a long-lost gleam returns to its skin – even the aroma of a freshly picked Boulderchip Mamango fills the air.
The fruit is plump, shiny and new again, as if it’d just ripened.
The Necromancer takes a tentative bite off it, and then seeks to hand me the rest.
Why would you bite a piece off that if you were going to offer it to me?
The ancients who looked after my village have taught us to do this as a sign of respect.
I suppose it fosters camaraderie, but more importantly it shows that what is offered cannot possibly be cursed, poisoned, or otherwise; lest both parties shall perish.
It must be a lovely place, then.
Hoping the words of Light would be enough to protect me, I go for a bite of the healed mamango. It tastes sweet and fresh. May the Light illuminate my path.
To be trusting and untrusting... My people learn to see those concepts as interchangeable.

Their gaze wanders off – far down the river.
Their brooding doesn’t make me feel as uneasy as before.
Why did you invite me here?
They just hold their gaze in the distance, perhaps taking in and pondering my question. Did I get too comfortable near the enemy?
I’ve been living in this castle for a while. I don’t get to see a living soul very often, definitely not one that doesn’t fear my very presence.
They sigh, and turn their gaze to me.
You don’t seem afraid.
I– I don’t?
Is that why you raise the dead? Because you’re lonely?
They slumps back, looking up, with their hands on the ground. There’s another sigh, they sound... frustrated.
That would be a different matter.
They nimbly stand and offer me their hand. I pretend not to notice and help myself up. I pat the dirt off my backside – the Necromancer’s robes are immaculate.
We should get going. You must be starving.

And I must note...
You sounded just as eager as I was for this engagement.
That’s just a tradition where I’m from.

passages.label: c14
passages.text: I am scared, at risk – yet I do not feel threatened. How can that be? I just feel... guilty, reprobate. At this very moment, I see myself where I saw the Necromancer just a while ago.
Baiting and feeding them hope. Planning the perfect moment to strike them down.
Although... I do suppose I did miss a couple of golden opportunities – am I losing my edge? Did I lose sight of my goal?
I– I must bid my time.

passages.label: c07
passages.text: Dragging the huge fish behind them, the Necromancer has taken me to their kitchen. The skeletons from before are gone, I see stains on the floor – probably where their stew spilled once they tried to eat it, the poor devils.
Dropping the monstrous fish on the counter, the Necromancer begins to chant words of darkness.
I do once more manage to understand a handful of them; some of those that have been taught to me by the Chamber – as words of healing.

Waving their hands and weaving their unholy magic above the kitchen’s many counters, the Necromancer begins reviving. The fish loses all of its undead tellings, becoming fresh and regaining the glistening of its scales.
As the Necromancer continues to pour life upon the onions and potatoes all around us, I can even spot flowers sprouting from the cracks on the walls.
Crushing a small chunk of coal in their hand, the Necromancer wills the logs under the oven ablaze with purple flames.
With a well sharpened knife, they clean and slice the fish to perfect, generously thick fillets, and sets all of the ingredients to cook.

passages.label: c14
passages.text: It’s not long before dinner’s ready – the Necromancer invites me to follow them to the dinner hall.
We pass by Amelia, the fortune teller, who seems to be supervising a pair of zombies who are trying to grab a large tome from the top of a tall shelf.
Her presence brings my worries back to surface. What secrets does she still hold? What does the Necromancer know?
Have I become too lost in the moment? Will I not forget my holy quest? As a Paladin of the Chamber – will I know to slay the Necromancer when I must?

passages.label: c15
passages.text: We reach the dining hall. It is cozier than I’ve imagined, not nearly as opulent as some of the other parts of the castle.
A well-crafted wooden table sits at the center of the hall, it’s not as long as one would expect the tables to be at a regal castle. It’s much more... personal.
A dozen skeletons suddenly rush into the room, what is going on?! I think a very small ghost is also among them.

The skeletons carry plates, glasses, platters and bottles. They rush rhythmically around the hall, spreading the tablecloth, setting the silverware down, lighting candles, making the room impeccable. The teeny ghost helps.
As quick as they’ve come in, they are now gone. The very tiny ghost waves goodbye before shutting the door behind them.
A single skeleton waiter stays behind, they pull a chair and invite me to sit, and then does the same for the Necromancer.
I try and make myself look comfortable as the skeleton pours us wine, and leaves to fetch the first course. I turn to the Necromancer, is this the perfect moment to strike? I can’t– I should–
I’m sure there must be something I don’t know yet.
How long have you been living in this castle?
I suppose it’s been a while over an year.
I already knew the answer to that question.
The skeleton waiter returns and lays our plates. The fish we’ve caught is now a luscious, perfectly roasted, fillet. Light forgive me, I try some of it. It tastes undeservingly heavenly.
The Necromancer signals for the skeleton to leave, they do. We’re once again left by ourselves.
I somehow don’t picture you as an aristocrat.
Neither do I, but it would make a vaguely accurate label. I was born Mavut Mayes, the grandchild of an estranged baroness, born and raised on a distant, foreign, perhaps primitive, land.
This castle is all of the inheritance left to my name.
What became of the family you’ve left behind?
I couldn’t know. I miss them terribly, yet I haven’t heard word ever since they’ve banished me from my homeland.
Why would they exile one of their own?
They used to turn a blind eye to how I challenged certain dogmas of our community. Until I, too eager to prove my worth, made irreparable mistakes... simply by following my nature.
Your people, your family – they condemned your dark magic.
Yes.
I feel like a terrible person. I’ve been imagining a big family of murder-happy hemomancers and demonologists merrily raising the dead and each other for fun and profit.
They have no one.
Why do you do it, then?
The power brought from forbidden words, all that cannot otherwise be achieved. To learn of the darkest arts is to forsake the inconveniences of a mortal life.
With my magic, I feel like I can do better by this Mud we live in. I feel like I can be myself, as I truly am, as I can truly be.

I often see no meaning in anything other than the calling to–
To improve my craft, I suppose.
The Necromancer takes pause, pensively prodding their meal. I catch myself doing the same, that’s a lot to take in.
Where do you come from, Lydia? Before you became an apprentice to Isabella, that is.
I hail from a long line of noble, proud, stuck up hoarders. Old money, old faith, old traditions.
I didn’t even have to make that up.
And how come they sent you to become a blacksmith at Bootscrape?
I suppose they don’t truly intend to have me become any sort of artisan. They just want me to upkeep their values – they hope I’ll build my character and find the shape of their moral principles.
How well is that working out for you?
I sip from my glass of wine. I realize I’ve been sipping it quite often for quite a while. So has the Necromancer.
I’m making steady progress.
Did I just say that out loud?
Although I fear I will not be forgiven if I don’t return with the exact answer I’ve been told to find.
Why would your family send you away if they don’t want you to become your own person?

While I do resent the hardships they’ve brought me... I do believe their morals to be right. I do agree that one must learn to do what is right by their own choice, other than only doing it because they are told.
This sounds... conflicting.
Every soul is illuminated with free will, not one is forced to follow any given path – yet there are paths laid out for those of us who wish to do good, to do what is right.
My Ord– my– my family certainly wouldn’t approve of ways such as yours. The path you follow is dark.
You don’t believe darkness can be a force for good.
Everything has a price. To raise the dead is to deny their path of Light, their peace and rest.
Your love of life is undeniable. Your family must be very religious.
Yes, very much so.
I wish master blacksmith Isabella were here to tell me to shut up.
Lydia, as abhorrent as it sounds, I value life just as much as you do. I believe all deserve to have as much of it as my powers allow.
Mavut Mayes, you’re an evil necromancer, raiser and enslaver of the dead.
And you, Lydia, if that’s your real name, are a Paladin from the Order of the Chamber of the Light.
I jump from my chair, it falls backwards with a loud thump. The glass in my hand shatters as I summon my hammer. There is no time to think, this is the moment.
These words of yours are meaningless. My interests are in keeping the people of Boulderchip alive, while yours are to see them – and I – dead.
You knew! Why did you let me in?!
Why do I feel betrayed? It was I who–
There’s very little I truly know, Lydia. It’s been a while since Amelia, the Cartomancer, came to warn me that there’s been someone from Bootscrape snooping around my grounds.
I knew there was a new arrive at the blacksmith shop. I knew – the moment I met you – that you were unlike anyone else I’ve met around these parts, you would not cower and whisper in my presence.
So I came to admire your boldness, your grit, and to suspect your purpose.
I took you fishing, I got to see how you fight... I’ve had little to no doubt since then. Yours are not the skills of a blacksmith’s apprentice, I’ve been challenged by your ilk before, Paladin.
Yet, as we battled side by side, you never thought to turn on me.
I don’t know what it is you intend, but listen well: you can not trick me.
What an absolute joke of a Paladin I am. I’ve always been the fish nibbling at the bait. From beginning to end.

What about you, Necromancer? If you can tell who I am by my skill alone, how come you didn’t take the chance to kill me while we fought the undead fish – or while I sat vulnerable within your walls, among your servants?!
I could still kill you.
I am now certain it would be within my right.
But I’ve come to cherish your presence, Lydia.
Stay as a guest of my castle. Give yourself a chance to find your own truth, give us a chance to find ourselves and each other.

There’s another way, Necromancer.
You forgot the option where I kill you.
That wouldn’t be possible even if you had your entire paladin order here with you. And they are definitely not known for showing up when they’re needed.
W– what do you mean?!
Where was the Chamber when Boulderchip first fell victim to the plague?
Well– they... they sent me.
I don’t doubt your goodwill, Lydia. But how foolish is it to trust the methods they’ve chosen? Their efforts are not to help the people.
The plague can’t be cured, there’s nothing that can be done other than– than...
With measured tranquility – and without breaking eye contact for even a second – the Necromancer rises from their chair, and slowly steps up to me.
Genocide.
Not genocide, quarantine! Containment! We block the roads, ease the pain, let nature run its course, and the Light shines their paths.
Is there a difference if you’re letting them all die? I’ve found my own ways of both ending their suffering and of sparing their lives.
By the Light, foul despot, you’re raising the dead!
Do they not want to be raised?!
The Necromancer sounds affected, they raise their voice. They’ve never done so before, it sounds so very much unlike them.
Us mortals are not to meddle with what is gifted to us by the Holy Light. Necromancer, you have no right to break the natural order!
I do what I can to help the people. People the Chamber has no problem ignoring and leaving to die.
What’s more, proud Paladin... it brings me joy, pure joy, to see those – who have once suffered – be given a second chance at life.
You’re beyond redemption, Necromancer. The powers you hold violate the laws of the Holy Light. Your necromancy is an unholy crime punishable by death.
I am warded, Lydia. Warded by spells bound to both this castle and the wills of all of my servants. If I were to die, they too would perish; and so would the very walls around us crumble to ruins.
If you must stand against me, it is my duty to fight for those I protect, those who protect me in kind.

The Necromancer produces their harpoon, completely cleaned after our previous clash, it glistens by the dim candlelight of the dining hall. I tighten the grip on my hammer, we both assume combat stances.
If you must fight for what you believe in, I shall deliver no mercy.  What you want, I cannot allow.
I tell you the same. The Light knows whose path to shine on.
I’m not bringing you back.
A gesture of respect?
ROLL FOR INITIATIVE

passages.label: lawfulend
passages.text: My hands are weak, tired, bruised. My hammer drops with a heavy, loud thud. I fall to my knees at the cold stone of the ruined tower, having exhausted my entire being.
The Necromancer’s body lies in front of me, colder than ever – dead. I’ve done it. I’ve achieved righteous victory, the will of the Light is done, evil is vanquished.
I’m having a hard time keeping my eyes open, I think I need to rest.
You will be missed, Mavut, but this Mud is better without you.

passages.label: c00
passages.text: YEARS LATER
It is known, the success of the campaign of the Order of the Chamber of the Light against the evil Necromancer who once ruled over the sorry village of Boulderchip, it is known.
She is known, Lydia Casquet, Paladin of the Order of the Chamber of the Light, vanquisher of the undead, exalted upholder of heavenly law.
She has defeated the evil Necromancer by her own hands, ended their rule of darkness by way of unparalleled might.
Lydia has since risen among the ranks of the Chamber, having accepted anointing by the highest Celestial Mothers and Fathers of the faith, being blessed by the Tallest Hierophants themselves.
Lydia Casquet has become a High Paladin of the uppermost orders of the Chamber.

Now a harrowing task stands before her. Lydia must lead a crusading Paladin campaign back to Boulderchip and beyond, erasing any remains of the curse of undeath, quarantining every infected village along the way.
Some would call this an impossible undertaking;  Lydia wouldn’t. She remains steadfast at the face of evil, she does not abide. The Mud shall be cleansed by her hand and hammer.
The Mud might truly be better for this.

passages.label: END
passages.text: LAWFUL GOOD END

passages.label: neutralend
passages.text: I stand before Mavut Mayes, the Necromancer, who kneels before me as the Holy Light begins dimming away from my body.
Tears run down my face as I too kneel before them. They don’t say a word, although I do believe I hear sobbing.
The Chamber be damned. We shall illuminate our own paths of Light.
I’m having a hard time keeping my eyes open, I think I need to rest.

passages.label: c00
passages.text: YEARS LATER
Considered criminal and profane by the deeply conservative orders of the coast, a new order of rebellious paladins has been amassing members and supporters across the ample countryside.
The people are tired of the neglect offered by orders such as the Chamber of the Light.
Paladins of the Eternal Order of Rebirth challenge the old dogmas of traditional faith.
These brave heroes dare to cast dark magic alongside the known spells of the Light. Their ranks are equally composed of healers and necromancers – who aid the living, and raise the dead.
As the plague continues to spread untamed across the Mud, paladins of the Eternal march on its wake, providing new life to those who lost theirs.
Leading the troops are Lydia Casquet, the Paladin Endarkened; and Mavut Mayes, the Necromancer Enlightened.
Together they struggle to ease the pains of a Mud forgotten by its gods, and to fight the plague no matter how, be it by healing hand, or by dark incantation.

Gossip around the inner circles of the Eternal is that Lydia and the Necromancer are fostering an affair of love, that their "urgent" meetings sometimes turn out to be intimate fishing trips, or lengthy dinner dates.
Although most are sure they couldn’t possibly have the time for love; and that two individuals from such disparate walks of life – and death – could never be an item.

Yet they do fish. Yet they do dine. Yet they do disagree on the matters of life, death, and rebirth. Yet they do – often – fight, to calamitous outcomes.
Yet – they never leave each-other’s side.
The truest of allies may indeed be those not afraid to quarrel.
The Mud might truly be better for this.

passages.label: END
passages.text: NEUTRAL GOOD END

My hands are weakened, tired. I put down my hammer.
The Necromancer drops their harpoon as well.
We both fall to our knees, facing each other, exhausted.
I’m having a hard time keeping my eyes open, I think I need to rest. We drop in exhaustion, the both of us, beside each other; I don’t know for how long we stay that way.
As the sun rises, I feel cold and lifeless hands holding me with delicate affection – carrying me off to somewhere.

passages.label: c00
passages.text: YEARS LATER

The plague has been vanquished, no longer do its vicious tendrils devastate the villages of the countryside.
The Order of the Chamber of the Light are next in line.
They now use its powerful rate of expansion to spread a different condition across the land: the cursed blessing of undeath.

As graveyards become vacant and armies are formed, the High Rulers – a wise Necromancer and a reformed Dark Paladin – shall soon lead the troops in battle against their greatest opposers: the Order of the Chamber of the Light.
All who dare to call undeath a profane heresy must be subjugated.
Lydia and the Necromancer are not afraid to murder, raze, and raise new life from the ashes – they are building a new world, one not blinded by light, one freed by darkness.
Lydia and the Necromancer are an unstoppable item, and many believe they foster a not-so-hidden love affair.
When not bringing forth the new tides of darkness, the odd pair can often be found fishing – fighting vicious creatures of the deep as if their blighted lives depended on it.
Perhaps the Mud lives better in darkness than it’s ever died in light.
The Mud might truly be better for this.

passages.label: END
passages.text: CHAOTIC GOOD END
